So say the dames with sorrowing heart,</br>As, tumult raising round and bustle,</br>The assembly one and all depart;</br>Shoes scrape the ground, and manteaux rustle.
The coast now clear, they quit the loft;</br>And one below begins to speak—</br>"Ye ghostly gossips, with whom oft</br>I mutter, or from closets shriek;
"The benches left awhile retain,</br>And here debate we, since the light</br>That sends each dy'd and darken'd pane</br>Consoles us for the loss of night.
"To what behaviour (strange, absurd,</br>I vow!) have we to-day been witness!</br>By'r Lady was the like e'er heard,</br>So opposite to form and fitness?
"Alas!  the sad degenerate times,</br>And fashion's mischievous abuses!</br>'Tis true, I cannot blame his rhymes,</br>But they are pitiful excuses;
"And, — by the saints, by Papal toes</br>I swear, and by Loretto's shrine—</br>To other consciences repose</br>May give, but ne'er can quiet mine.
"How then revenge us on the age?—</br>Our Queen hath set a meet example.</br>Shall we in general schemes engage?</br>Or on this single Poet trample?
"Once form and orthodoxy join'd—</br>The faggot flamed — How matters alter!</br>Now felony, crime of venial kind,</br>Alone seems worthy of the halter."
She sate:  upstarted with a frown,</br>A second, in appearance older,</br>And, slow as she arose, look'd down</br>Alternately on either shoulder.
Then, with cross'd hands and solemn mien,</br>Thus answer'd:  "Cry you mercy, Madam!</br>Ask you if e'er the like was seen?</br>No, never since the time of Adam!
"But in this circle if ye sit</br>A signal vengeance to devise,</br>Your loving sister sprite permit</br>What most may further us, to advise.
"'Twere just in truth, and fully due,</br>That all should feel retaliation,</br>Who every system thus o'erthrew</br>We formed to benefit the nation.
"But seeing this 'tis now no time for,</br>(Howe'er they ought to undergo it;)</br>And as a notion strikes me — I'm for</br>Attacking the obnoxious poet.
"For know, in early youth, the law</br>Was first the project of that fellow.</br>COKE still the manor's guardian saw,</br>With pleasure, saw his genius mellow.
"But, all relinquished for his Muse,</br>Has born him since a deadly grudge:</br>His hopes no longer in him views;</br>No longer sees the future judge.
"To him then haste we, to implore</br>The mightier aid his wisdom boasts:</br>Great among mortals heretofore,</br>As great we'll prove him among ghosts.
"The garret, where he used to rave,</br>He haunts; the wing, in which below</br>Slept once, and once her audience gave,</br>His Queen, Elizabeth, our foe.
"Nor deem that he, a Protestant,</br>Will with us doubt to coalesce.</br>Experience vouches that he can't;</br>The power of interest all confess."
At this the dames assenting all,</br>To seek the Knight and open their case,</br>Slide without tread across the hall,</br>And wind together up the staircase.
Spirits are ne'er by bolts confin'd,</br>Or bars, and short the matter hence cut;</br>For those, who crannies cannot find,</br>Squeeze through the cieling or the wainscot.
With wary watchfulness they sweep</br>Slow along unfrequented paths;</br>Now behind beams and rafters creep,</br>Now 'twixt the bared and broken laths.
At length, a closet without door</br>Displays to each the lonely Judge,</br>Apart, and stretch'd upon the floor;</br>As spirits, slow ere dusk to budge.
In such plight, piteous to behold,</br>As waiting erst the hour of death:—</br>Alas!  how changed from him of old,</br>Who scared bandittis with his breath!
His voice, the garb in which he's clad,</br>And aspect, every terror mingle;</br>And the same chains that bound him mad,</br>Now, hanging round about him, jingle:
Such as, to fall when the dew begins,</br>Homeward the villager repairing</br>From plough, at distance, for his sins,</br>Perceives him at the window staring.
The prudes accost him with a smile,</br>And court'sy low and reverential:</br>"Bright star," they cry, "of this our isle,</br>Glory of Jurisprudence, when shall
"Your slaves prevail on you to hear 'em,</br>Unfold a high and weighty matter?</br>Let not religion make you fear 'em,</br>Nor will it, as ourselves we flatter.
"Deign then, descending now with us</br>Ev'n to the hall we scarcely quit,</br>Our urgent business to discuss;</br>'Tis yours; as hearing you'll admit."
Long cross-legg'd held by mute Suspense,</br>Sudden he cries — "With Papists? — Humph!</br>But it may profit me; — Then hence,</br>Ye scruples! — Sister spirits, come."
He rises, down the steps all haste;</br>The Knight parading in the middle,</br>As by his suite a monarch graced;</br>Their meaning ardent to unriddle.
Soon as again they reach the room,</br>He sinks in Cobham's chair; around him</br>The rest their places thick resume:</br>And, at the tale's beginning, sound him;
Then show the Poet dared excite</br>Their own, no less than his, resentment;</br>Whence modern pertness punish'd, might</br>Give him and them alike contentment.
Yet for his honour they declare,</br>Most, in the lordship's, they complain'd;</br>And end, imputing to his share</br>Some misdemeanors they had feign'd:
"That at the door he rudely rapp'd,</br>Slander'd the Lady in her presence;</br>And oft, at monstrous mischief apt,</br>Had soil'd her robe, and spilt her essence."
By their persuasive accents won,</br>Himself he feels for, then he pities:—</br>What has not woman's influence done,</br>Before and since the Syren's ditties?
And thus he cries, "enraged, the wretch</br>I find on new pursuits escape me,</br>Who my resemblance well might catch,</br>Though vainly many lawyers ape me.
"For this, ye walls that long have known</br>Your Lord deceased and living both;</br>Seen me rejoice, and heard me groan;</br>Be witnesses of this my oath.
"If the aerial ministers,</br>To manage human things departed,</br>I can induce to aid my stirs,</br>And plans of hate so deeply rooted;
"If I can aught of use contrive,</br>To accomplish some vindictive work,</br>To which those agents I may drive</br>By fair persuasion, or by quirk;
"He must, I see, to glory rise—</br>Perhaps too in some abbey choir,</br>Where less the heart will sympathize,</br>A cenotaph may grace his lyre;
"But if I can avail, when brought</br>With dirges due to that church-yard</br>He sung, in strain pathetic, nought</br>Shall mark where sleeps the fav'rite bard.
"And though each way the crowded place</br>Should number every pauper's days,</br>HIM not the unletter'd Muse shall grace,</br>Ev'n with the pittance of her praise."</br>
